doc.content:
Emojis seem to suffer from visible image compression and seem to have broken transparency. Please use lossless compression with proper transparency instead.
Dear Telegram developers,

the Emojis in Telegram for Android seem to suffer from visible image compression, which gets especially noticeable upon increasing the message font size (which makes the Emojis become larger as well).

To me it looks like as if the Emojis would be images which are compressed using JPEG or something like that and as if they would have a lot of compression and maybe even chroma subsampling (4:2:0) applied to them.

In addition, the transparency of the images seems to be somewhat broken, because you can see a faint rectangle behind/around them.

Unfortunately I don't know where those images are stored on GitHub, so I don't know how to look at them with a PC. Therefore I can only tell from looking at them from inside the Telegram Android app.

And from there it looks like as described above.

So, could you please use lossless compression without chroma subsampling (i.e. with full chroma resolution, i.e. 4:4:4) for them instead? Like PNG for example?

It would be much appreciated.

Regards

comments.content: Emoji textures was saved as jpeg for reduce it's size. Alpha channel also saved in jpeg as grayscale image. Size is critical for android 2.x devices. Also loading jpeg is faster then png. No other solution for it until I will drop 2.x support.

@DrKLO could you please at least save them without chroma subsampling (i.e. full chroma resolution, i.e. 4:4:4)?

Please see what chroma subsampling does to colors:

Without chroma subsampling (4:4:4):

![rgbk3olr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7558360/6662225/0827d33c-cbb9-11e4-9299-dfcbaf7b4d04.png)

![yuv420amq5v](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7558360/6662230/24c85b1a-cbb9-11e4-9336-c41feea24a55.png)

As you can see, the image with chroma subsampling (4:2:0) looks much worse than the picture without chroma subsampling (4:4:4).

JPEG allows for saving images without chroma subsampling.

So, could you please try to compress the Emojis with JPEG but with chroma subsampling disabled, so that they will retain their full chroma resolution (i.e. be 4:4:4)?

It would be much appreciated.

It would be really nice if you could do that at the very least.

And it would be even nicer if you could also try to increase the JPEG quality a bit. As mentioned above, the Emojis currently seem to be compressed with a JPEG quality of 62 only, which is very very low.

Maybe you could increase it to a somewhat higher quality value?

How about 80? Or 90? Or someting in between? Or maybe even 100?

Could you please try? It would be much appreciated.

Oh, and another, alternative question:

> @DrKLO wrote:
> 
> Size is critical for android 2.x devices.
> Also loading jpeg is faster then png.
> No other solution for it until I will drop 2.x support.

With "2.x devices" you are referring to Android 2.x devices, aren't you?

So, how about using JPEGs for those old Android 2.x devices and using PNGs for all later devices (4.x, 5.x and so on)?

Would that be possible?

It would be really nice if you would reply.

After having increased the message font size and then having seen the compression artifacts on the Emojis in Telegram for Android, I can hardly unsee it, even when the Emojis are smaller.

I compared them to some 160x160 PNGs found on the internet, and they look a lot better (cleaner, sharper, better colors).

So it would be really nice if you could do something about it.

Regards

Some groups can grow quite big (up to 200 members) and some members can be quite chatty.

Not only does this create an issue in terms of notifications (as discussed in #738 ) but it makes the actual chat screen very verbose. 

I'd suggest that in group chat, consecutive messages by the same member automatically collapse after 2 or 3 messages, followed by a "more" link that when pressed expands to reveal the remaining messages, turning the "more" into a "less" link to collapse the messages again if necessary.

You find this message collapsing/expansion in several other social network contexts, but in this case I think it's best applied to consecutive messages rather than single, lenghty, messages.

It also works well for accidental message sending, such as when someone's cat walks across their keyboard when AFK.

doc.content:
Text Avatar for groups and users with no photo
Two changes are proposed here:
1- Group names doesn't have a last name field, so if a group has a name of two words such as "Test Group" then Telegram for Android will only show the first letter T only (while Telegram Web and desktop show TG), so if there is no last name simply check if the first name has a space separating two or more words and use the first letter from the last word.

2- In languages like Arabic, letters that are have no space in between will usually link to each other, but in case of initials they should be separate, so I propose the use of "Zero-width non-joiner" character between the two letters which will make the letters display as stand-alone (non-joined) also it has no effect on other languages like English.

Image after applying the group name fix (groups now have two letters)
![tel_joiner](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/432460/6009699/219b0904-aafa-11e4-8371-53a1dc53f9ac.png)

![tel_non-joiner](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/432460/6009704/384adabc-aafa-11e4-95de-2561e21d0cfd.png)

More info about Zero-width non-joiner can be found here:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-width_non-joiner

doc.content:
Emoji issue (replacing with others)
This has been a common issue over here AFAIK with several other issues also discussing about the current emoji choices.

The problem is that the current emoji font used (Apple Color Emoji, also used by WhatsApp) etc. is not the favorite of everyone, and even worse, it's actually under Apple's copyright. Under some sources that I could find (like [this](http://words.steveklabnik.com/emoji-licensing), [this](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10834811/emoji-copyright) and [this](https://github.com/github/gemoji/pull/64)), it's shady (if not illegal) to distribute the emoji font like Telegram does now.

The choices are to use the system's own emoji or open-source free emoji fonts (such as Google's [Noto](https://www.google.com/get/noto/), which is licensed under Apache 2 and should be available as PNG as well).

EDIT: Some additional comments that they look out of place in an application that is designed to be Material Design for Android, so stock emojis on the system would be the best option. Also, using the argument of "[I don't like Android emojis](https://github.com/DrKLO/Telegram/issues/358#issuecomment-45840820)" is not a good argument in my opinion, considering the application has a particularly large user base which may have a great amount of users who don't like iOS emojis.

doc.content:
Reverse order of messages in notifications
With the notifications as they are now, they go bottom-to-top, as shown here:

![yo!](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4363779/5993266/d86c945a-aa4a-11e4-9237-398dfa9e8b26.png)

Note how the first message gets put on the bottom, and the later ones get put on top. This should be changed for the other way around, for two very simple reasons:

* It's confusing with the messages appearing in this order - you naturally read bottom-to-top, not top-to-bottom.
* In-app, Telegram renders new messages under ones previous. This makes for a confusing design inconsistency.

A change should be made to show new messages under the ones before, even in the notifications.

doc.content:
Feature suggestion: Message types + filter on these types
It's my experience that often important messages get lost in the bulk of chat conversations. A solution could be to implement message types and the option to filter on these types. 

Message types are already partially implemented. Telegram has "special" messages like images, stickers, documents, locations. I would suggest to expand on these types. Specifically calendar dates would be really useful. It's probably the biggest use case scenario of Telegram for people to plan a date. These special messages could be added through the "attachment" button in the chat client. 

Other (interactive) types might be polls (group decisions), checklists (to-do's) or starred messages. Although the interactive nature of such messages might be more difficult to implement. 

Most importantly, it would be great if we could filter on message types. Include a filter icon in the top-right of the chat with: images, links, dates, documents, locations, starred messages. 

I believe these additions could enable Telegram to become a much stronger social productivity / collaboration tool (positioning itself somewhere between Whatsapp and Facebook). 

It would perhaps also eliminate/reduce the need for search (a feature which has a much bigger impact on the back-end load).

doc.content:
FEATURE REQUEST: Information Message for Users & Groups
Telegram is becoming more and more a behemoth of awesome features. I am currently on several groups and have more than 100 contacts using it, 2 similar features would help in how Telegram is presented to new users:

1. Information Messages for User - This note style information box would show more information about a particular contact. Currently we only have the phone number and username. Other options could be added like where the user works, profession or simply dynamically giving the user the option to add several fields or text area type fields to add their user information. This way, other contacts know that this user has this type of profession, likes X type of stuff and more. This of course, limited to a permission based system where the contact can choose which input field to share or not.

2. Information Messages for Groups - Similar to the user one but focused on what the group is all about, what it does, the rules or general guidelines that members of said group will follow and anything similar in that aspect.

comments.content:
I have no opinion about point 2., but I do about point 1.: the idea sounds great. However, I think in general we should refrain our prefered pieces of software from doing everything, and encourage each to do one simple job and do it well, while seeking interoperability (and that's key). Telegram is for IM, so let's have it do awesome IM. Other apps or services are for contact information, and can perform that job in awesome ways. And let them just communicate with one another. For example if you want to start/suggest/participate on an app that would allow people to publish contact information about themselves, it would be great. Then Telegram would be able to access that information.

As one example among others, there are Yellow Pages services that some addressbook apps (e.g. the one in Cyanogenmod, but I don't know about other versions of Android) already use. Maybe the Telegram client app or the Telegram server can query that as well since Telegram knows your phone number, and present it. It's just an example to show what you can do with interoperability as opposed to trying to do everything yourself, in your own closed way.

To show it the other way round: if you store and maintain information about yourself in the Telegram network, next step you'll want to share that information to other apps or people that are possibly unrelated to Telegram, in order to not maintain that information in several places, which nobody likes to do. So Telegram will in fact become a contact information provider, and as such it will have to implement e.g. a REST API and whatnot. You don't want to open that can of worms.

doc.content:
Impossible to delete pending messages
Steps to reproduce the bug:

- Make sure your phone is completely off-line
- Send a message to a Cloud Chat
- Try to select and delete this pending message.

==> Impossible. No way to delete pending messages to avoid that they are sent as soon as on-line connection is available again. (Secret Chats are not affected by this bug.)

[Telegram for Android v2.2.1 (409)]

comments.content:
The reason for this behavior are buggy older Android systems (<4.4), where the system always returns that there's an internet connection — so we never know whether our query actually made it to the server until we get a response. This response can be delayed due to the same poor Internet connection that caused the message to stay unsent long enough for you to reconsider.

If we allow messages to be deleted in this unsent state, it could frequently lead to situations where you'll think you've deleted the message before it could be sent — but it had been sent in fact and the recipient will get it. 

More than that: since you can only delete something from your cloud when you know its id on the server, this deletion before we get a response will only result in deleting the local object in the database — which means that if the message was in fact sent, it will be resurrected in the user's conversation on next sync.

comments.content:
Unfortunately I have to agree with @stefan-niedermann -- any project operated in such a manner is not, by definition, an open source project.

Here's a good rule of thumb:  If at any point a user cannot make a build of the app that is identical to the distributed version (barring of course things like code signing), then it's not open source.

Frankly, I find this fairly disturbing.  It means there's secret code in the app that I can't audit or review for myself.

For an app that sells itself on the promise of security, the inability to audit the code for the version that's in the store is especially troubling.

doc.content:
Messenger for Telegram trying to connect to unsucesfully servers during PowerNap darkwake on OSX 10.9.5
Ciao, 

I am seeing strange logs from many installation of osx and telegram beta (latest, as of today 10.30.1050 ).

The application many times keeps trying to connect to servers unsuccessfully during the usual hourly powerNap dark wake. If seems osx prevents the application from connecting to internet so that power consumption is useless.

[MTTcpTransport#0x6180001158d0 system sleep detected, resetting connection]

Moreover if application keeps running during dark wake there will be (I suppose) some inconsistency between memory footprint ad filesystem. In the case that the mac decides to hybernate because of SafeSleep the sleep image /var/vm/sleepimage will be taken during first sleep and not updated at every PowerNap wake up. In the case Messenger writes to the filesystem during darkwake and battery goes down during restore from image the memory will be "rolledback" while filesystem has been update thus creating inconsistency (I suppose).

I suppose the last potential problem would be common to all darkwake running applications.

Greetings,
ACF

doc.content:
Grammar issue when forwarding messages, Korean translation
When you forward messages to a contact or a group, the same translation is used for both contacts and groups - this cannot be fixed by changing translations.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Run Telegram in Korean, on Android.
2. Forward a message to a contact.
3. Forward a message to a group.
4. Note confirmation dialog, for example:  
"Contact name"님에게 메시지를 전달할까요?  
>>>"Group name"님에게 메시지를 전달할까요?<<<
5. ---> Same translation is used for both contacts and groups - this can make translations sound **awkward** because in Korean, different wording is used for groups vs a person. (A group is being treated like a person.)

A potential fix would be to keep the following, but add a "forward to group" variant string:

- `<string name="ForwardMessagesTo">%1$s님에게 메시지를 전달할까요?</string>`

Korean expectation:

-  "Group name"에 전달하시겠습니까?

comments.content:
Device: OnePlus One
Android Version: CyanogenMod 11s - 4.4.4

I've disable Google+ and BANG, I'm not able to choose an image anymore (the app does nothing).
This is due to the fact that CyanogenMod 11s has a custom Gallery and not the default one.

But this is not an issue of my phone is a problem about the Intent you are using.

ACTION_PICK:
http://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/Intent.html#ACTION_PICK

     Input: getData() is URI containing a directory of data (vnd.android.cursor.dir/*) from which to pick an item.

This is meant for loading a content from an URI.

While

ACTION_GET_CONTENT:
http://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/Intent.html#ACTION_GET_CONTENT

    Activity Action: Allow the user to select a particular kind of data and return it. This is different than ACTION_PICK in that here we just say what kind of data is desired, not a URI of existing data from which the user can pick. An ACTION_GET_CONTENT could allow the user to create the data as it runs (for example taking a picture or recording a sound), let them browse over the web and download the desired data, etc.

This is meant for getting content (in your case an image) from whatever the user chooses.

doc.content:
Please, stop compressing images until nothing remains of them.
I just sent an image (with text) of 3286x1080 to a group conversation. On the image they received, nobody could make out what was supposed to be on the image, since it had been reduced to 800 pixels in width.
We're a geeky bunch. We often send out screenshots of something interesting, or our desktops. It's useless. Nobody on the receiving end can make out properly what is in the images.
I realise that compressing images can be useful for bandwidth preservation, and it probably is if the user is connected to the internet through their mobile network. Otherwise, there's a good chance all the compression is going to do is annoy them.
Please, at least give us the option to disable or decrease the compression. If we send someone an image, we want the receiver(s) to be able to see what's in the image. If we didn't want them to see anything, we wouldn't have sent it in the first place.

I realise that we can circumvent this by sending the image as a file instead, but that's not as convenient for the receivers of the image, as it does not give them a preview and requires them to download the file first rather that just immediately being able to view it.

Possible solutions:
* Keep this as the default behaviour, but include an option for images to not be compressed (preferably on the receiving end).
* Keep this as the default behaviour, but include a simple button that allows users to get the high-res version of the image.
* Only send the thumbnail to the user, and automatically download the high-res version when the user views the image.
* Show thumbnails for images that are sent using the *File* option (making the *Image* option useless in the first place, so you might as well just get rid of it).
* Download high-res images when the user is conencted to wifi, and keep the current behaviour for when the user is connected to the internet using a mobile network.

![Compressed screenshot. If you can tell me what's in here, you probably hacked into my computer to get the original image.](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3089559/3971396/45f4adbe-27d3-11e4-8169-d0e76338b057.png)

doc.content:
More/other options for time-window of self-destruction
Currently the self-destruct timer allows to destruct messages after
* 1 second
* 2 seconds
* 5 seconds
* 1 minute
* 1 hour
* 1 day
* 1 week

There are usecases when you want to give your chat partner a quick look at the message/attachment. In experiments, 1, 2 and 5 seconds were not long enough because when using the 5 second timer sometimes the message appears is only visible for a few milliseconds before it disappears for the receiver.

Also the given options do not always fit the length of the message: Some messages might need about 20 seconds to read.

Therefore I think it makes sense to add a choice for at least 15 and 30 seconds or maybe use an interactive slider ([with steps?](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/ui/custom-components.html))

comments.content:
If FLAG_SECURE crashes older android devices, check the API level before setting it. I think you are not understanding the purpose here. It's not so much preventing a screenshot but preventing the private messages from showing up in the app switcher. I don't want potentially sensitive messages or photos to appear in the app switcher.

The Telegram protocol is supposed to be about security and privacy, especially the secret chats. To this end, the app should provide options enhance privacy and security as much as possible. One way in which both are compromised is when you receive a message the sender's contact name is always shown. The secure lock screen doesn't leak this information, but the notification pulldown does and the unlocked notification bar does. I don't want to be showing something on my phone to a friend and have the notification "Slutty McHugeTits sent you a message." pop up. Or having to worry about a girl looking over my shoulder on a date and seeing "Monica Lewinsky sent you a photo." and having the inevitable "WHO IS MONICA LEWINSKY" discussion.

I would also like to see the entire app and its data able to be protected by a passphrase so that the chat database is secure. If I was a reporter working in, say, Egypt, this would be very important to me. Bypassing a lock screen can be pretty trivial, but if the database is strongly encrypted then your secret chats are safe from the police. There is also the problem of the app leaking information in the cache directory, but I think if you are that paranoid then full filesystem encryption might be warranted.

doc.content:
New AndroidManifest.xml merger doesn't merge the "installLocation" attribute
@DrKLO I noticed that the AndroidManifest.xml merger of the new gradle plugins (version 0.11.+) doesn't merge the attribute "android:installLocation" of the root tag, so the resulting apk can't be moved to sd card.
I managed to solve this problem by adding the attribute inside the following files:

TMessagesProj/config/debug/AndroidManifest.xml, TMessagesProj/config/foss/AndroidManifest.xml, TMessagesProj/config/release/AndroidManifest.xml

like this:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<manifest xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    package="org.telegram.messenger"
    android:installLocation="auto"> <!-- I added this line -->
<!-- the rest of the file is unchanged -->
</manifest>
```

Proxy server support

comments.content:
In some devices (such as samsung samsung galaxy s5 and note3), there is the function of the multiwindows. Basically you can use two apps that use each half of the screen (Screen example http://goo.gl/uYpXgl ). To add it, simply edit the manifest file of the app in this way:

add <category android:name="android.intent.category.MULTIWINDOW_LAUNCHER" /> in the main activity

like:
before:
<intent-filter>
                <action android:name="android.intent.action.MAIN" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.LAUNCHER" />
</intent-filter>

after:
<intent-filter>
                <action android:name="android.intent.action.MAIN" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.LAUNCHER" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.MULTIWINDOW_LAUNCHER" />
</intent-filter>

and add in tag <application>

<uses-library android:required="false" android:name="com.sec.android.app.multiwindow" />
    <meta-data android:name="com.sec.android.support.multiwindow" android:value="true" />
    <meta-data android:name="com.sec.android.multiwindow.DEFAULT_SIZE_W" android:value="632.0dip" />
    <meta-data android:name="com.sec.android.multiwindow.DEFAULT_SIZE_H" android:value="598.0dip" />
    <meta-data android:name="com.sec.android.multiwindow.MINIMUM_SIZE_W" android:value="632.0dip" />
    <meta-data android:name="com.sec.android.multiwindow.MINIMUM_SIZE_H" android:value="598.0dip" />

source: http://www.anddev.it/index.php/topic,12638.msg65995.html
http://www.modaco.com/page/news/_/android/developers-add-support-for-samsung-multi-window-to-your-apps-r823

doc.content:
Fixed issue #125 - push notifications do not always work
Problem is that the code which sends the request to the GCM is inside an AsyncTask and since Froyo tasks are run serially, so if another task starts before it and doesn't finish it doesn't run.
The fix is to use the new API of executeOnExecutor which runs the task in parallel to other tasks.

doc.content:
New features, some of them solving open issues
I have implemented some features that people usually  request to Support Force Team:

1. **Confirmation when creating a new secret chat:** according to issue #241
2. **Confirmation when sharing contact info:** As it is an option that appears on top of chat when contact don't know your number, I think (and so do some other member of Spanish Support Force) that it is a good idea to ask for confirmation, to avoid unintentionally clicks.
3. **Only wifi Automatic Download:** As an option in settings for Audio and photos, according to issue #146. It can also be helpful to save data, when then people, like me, have a limit of 1GB or even less.
4. **Add Version Info in Settings:** A new section have been added in settings (at the bottom) that shows currently version name, according to issue #391.
5. **Show/Hide Last Connection:** This is the hardest one because with current API the only way (the one I used) is to avoid client sending "online" notification to servers, so other users can't know if I am online; they will only know the time when I decided to hide it as my "last connection time". According to this, this feature is client dependent so if using another client without this feature, this client will send "online" info and contact wil know it.
6. Finally I added some strings needed to strings.xml (in English and Spanish).

There are some changes in *build.gradle* that I needed in order to compile my app correctly, but don't think they are needed in official version (except changing version number).

doc.content:
Render Markdown
#102 mentions implementation of some HTML-like formatting. I think it would be wiser to use something like Markdown instead, for the following reasons:
- It's already widely used, so many people are used to it.
- Even when it's not rendered graphically, it still makes sense. For example, \*hello\* should render as *hello*, but even if the text is displayed as is, you understand that I'm emphasising. If you see \*\*this\*\*, it's clear to you that I'm **insisting**.
- There are many libraries that can parse it easily, so implementation should not be a problem.
- *Not* using an existing standard would mean creating yet another one, which would be a terribly confusing thing to do.
- Any other arguments? (I will update the issue if/as more arguments appear.)

Other related feature requests could be submitted as well, such as a toolbar for entering such formatted text, but I think that *rendering* Markdown would be a sensible first step.

Arguments against using Markdown:
- Markdown doesn't do colours. On the other hand, IRC and particularly mIRC kids taught us that excess of colours is generally not very much appreciated. If you implement displaying colours, you also need to provide a way to *not* display them, since many people don't like them.
- Anything else? (I will update the issue if/as more arguments appear.)

Of course, Markdown defines semantics, not aspect. For example, there would be nothing wrong about rendering \*\*strong\*\* text as bold and blue, or even just blue. @fduraibi implemented a Markdown-like language that renders ^this^ as blue, for example. The important part is that it's emphasis. Think CSS.

For the sake of honesty, I should mention that I'm not particularly a big fan or user of formatting in instant messaging myself, because personally I use IM for communicating quickly, not for *redacting*. But I do respect that some people do need formatting, so I'm trying to propose a clean way to do that.

comments.content: When dealing with open protocols such as Telegram's, we always need to keep in mind that we might receive input written by people who use a different piece of software than we do, such as Webogram or Telegram for iOS. This is why this particular issue focuses on *rendering* a given input. In other terms: - It directly addresses the question "How should I render a received text that contains \*foo\*?". (And the proposed answer is: parse it as Markdown.) - It doesn't directly address the question "How should I *send* text with a part of it stressed?" (a.k.a. semantics). Asterisks or underscores are always nice candidates though, especially (but not only) when you know the receiving part will make sense of them. - It does absolutely not address the question "How do I send bold, italics, blue text or red text?" (a.k.a. graphics). In HTML, the \ years have long shown how bad an idea they were, but if anybody thinks it is indeed important to send colours with no particular semantics, that would fit in a different issue. I'm sure colours would be a nice tool to take advantage of on the rendering side though. If you haven't yet, I suggest you read [that introduction to Markdown](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/basics) first, and see where colours could help. One idea would be: - Render emphasis (\*foo\* in Markdown, \foo\ in HTML) with that light blue you're already using. Default style in web browsers is italics, but it's only a default, and never an obligation. - Render strong emphasis (\*\*foo\*\* in Markdown, \foo\ in HTML) with dark red + bold. Default style in web browsers is black and bold, but colours would certainly add to the effect! - Don't forget the "strong emphasis inside an emphasised text" case, or the reciprocal one. - Maybe render links as just underlined (plus bold? not sure...). In any case, and if I may insist: "How could I send blue/red/green text?" would be off-topic here (and in my humble opinion a misfeature). @fduraibi and others, what's your opinion? On a different matter, @fduraibi : I don't understand how slow phones are impacted by rendering, but I'm not an Android expert at system level. Is formatting very resource consuming? I do agree that rendering should be possible to disable anyway, just intrigued by the "slow phones" bit.

doc.content:
Forwarded message from! Who likes this feature?
One of the most annoying features in Telegram is this "Forwarded message From ...." tag that gets attached to any message (text, photo or video) that you forward from other people. And that was the main reason for me forking this repo and creating a way to get rid of it.

The only times i find it useful is when I am quoting someone saying something personal, but never saw it useful for forwarding a joke, generic information, video, photo...etc

The way I implemented my solution is by resending the message as if was originated from the sender. But I don't like this approach since it means resending big video files for every recipient which defeats the resharing of the same object that is already shared on Telegram server. But that is the only way right now since Telegram links each object to its original sender (As far as I understood) while e.g./ whatsapp will allow resharing but without any association to anyone.

* Why I don't like the forwarded from tag?
Mainly for privacy reasons, when I get a funny video, photo or text messages from the internet and I forward it to a friend, then that friend forwards it to his friends I don't want to be associated with some of these messages. Secondly:  i am mostly not the original author of the things i send so it is not my right to link my name to them, this is not twitter. And it is not just me who don't like it, all people I know who came from whatsapp don't like it.

* Solution?
The way I solved it in my forked repo is by having an option in the settings to turn on and off the "Forwarded..." tag, if you turn it off the app will resend as if the original sender (see the changes here  https://github.com/fduraibi/Telegram/commit/4375bd22f0465eda9cbeaf62b4ce119b2e942fd4 and here https://github.com/fduraibi/Telegram/commit/46beaddac8e2f03b66c2f76069446c4cf96eed22).
However, a nicer solution would be to add a new option in the message menu, so in addition to ```Forward``` which should send the message without forwarding tag we need another option e.g. ``` Quote and Forward``` that will keep the name of the original sender. Something like this:
![tele-bug3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/432460/2779465/4faec06c-cafc-11e3-9183-012af015c518.png)

So what do you users and developers think? do you like the app the way it is now, or you like such an option implemented?

doc.content:
Problem when sharing animated gif from other applications
Animated gifs shared from other applications will be decoded as jpeg and so they will not be animated anymore. This happens only if the other application shares the gif via [```FileProvider```](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v4/content/FileProvider.html) (when the uri is something like: ```content://xxx.yyy.zzz/fileprovider/animation.gif```). Normal non-animated images can be shared via [```FileProvider```](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v4/content/FileProvider.html) .

Everything works fine if the other application is sharing the image using uri starting with ```file://...```.

I tried this with a small test application i created. I also tried changing the mime type from ```image/gif``` to ```application/octet-stream``` (when sharing with the [```FileProvider```](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v4/content/FileProvider.html) ), but i got toast saying: "Unsupported content" and I can not share the image at all. 

```application/octet-stream``` also works if the uri starts with ```file://```.

Btw, the problem also occurs when I choose to share an image from Telegram chat activity ("Gallery" option from the drop down list). If I use the "Document" option and then select the same gif, it will work as expected.

comments.content:
I didn't dive deeply into the source code but seems that Telegram assigns a default color value for each account the first time, so it happens that in the same group two or more people have the same colour.. you should assign a different color for each account in groups and the colors you use must be easily distinguishable, so they can't be generated with a simple random function on RGB values but using HSV and Golden Ratio approach (http://devmag.org.za/2012/07/29/how-to-choose-colours-procedurally-algorithms/). After that, using a random value mixed with Golden Ratio for H and varying S and V you can get a lot of colors to pick. 

You can also consider a simpler approach:

1) in groups with less than 30 members, assign a color to each member of the group, picked from a set of 30 different, statically declared colors.

2) in groups with more than 30 members, use 1) for the first 30 members and generate a random RGB for the other ones.

This should be easier to implement and give a pretty good result in most cases.

I agree with @paraquake on the use of a transparent png with a white human head and change the background at runtime, for the color selection you can use one of these approaches.

(Proposed fix) Adding subject/title to some shared links (e.g. Youtube video title)
I have mentioned this before in issue #102 and here is a proposed solution that works for all the test cases that I have tried: https://github.com/fduraibi/Telegram/commit/977efef7795d732ba4d5f5bb49fcf49734e5a94c

First lets analyze the problem. When sharing something (article, youtube video, website) with Telegram the application that is doing the sharing will send the URL of that object to Telegram, however, applications differ in the way they do it. For example when sharing something from Firefox, Chrome, Youtube then "EXTRA_TEXT" will contain only the URL while "EXTRA_SUBJECT" will contain the title:
```
EXTRA_TEXT = 'http://www.youtube.com/something'
EXTRA_SUBJECT = 'Watch "Some video" on Youtube'
```

While in other apps like Flipboard or Google Play Newsstand the "EXTRA_TEXT" will contain the title of that shared article and the URL:
For Newsstand:
```
EXTRA_TEXT = 'This is something cool http://www.something.com'
EXTRA_SUBJECT = 'This is something cool'
```

For Flipboard:
```
EXTRA_TEXT = 'This is something cool http://www.something.com'
EXTRA_SUBJECT = 'Article: This is something cool'
```

so in my proposed fix first I added this
```
String subject = intent.getStringExtra(Intent.EXTRA_SUBJECT);
```
to get the subject

and then this if statement 
```
if ( text.startsWith("http://") && subject != null && subject.length() != 0 ) {
```
to make sure that "EXTRA_TEXT" doesn't contain the subject already (so we wont have a duplicate title like the case with flipboard and newsstand) and that subject is not null or empty.

![screenshot_2014-03-08-01-42-16](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/432460/2366484/b109f6c8-a708-11e3-85db-6298f51c93e1.png)

Note: I didn't do a pull request since I couldn't find an easy way to only submit certain commits (it involves branching and other complicated stuff beyond my knowledge) and since @DrKLO uses his own private repo for coding, so submitting something to the public one might be useless. @DrKLO if you like my solution feel free to copy and paste it into your main repo.

However, i vote for simply removing the "://" to make it **startsWith("http")** which seems good enough since anything that starts with **http** is mostly a URL!

doc.content:
Fixed Audio Recording
Your Audio recording code is not working ( on Samsung Galaxy S3 ).
The problem is the Sampling rate 24,000 is no official rate.
I replaced it with 16,000 Hz ( see on http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sampling_rate )
=> That is the usual VoIP quality.

Also your Encoding Bitrate is wrong (or at least not usual )
The formula for the Bitrate is 
``` Bit rate = (sampling rate) × (bit depth) × (number of channels) ```

The normal bit depth on Android is 8 but I used 4 because it keeps the files much smaller and the quality difference isn't that much ( still noticable )

If it's still too big the Sampling rate can be decreased to 11,025 Hz or 8,000 Hz but the Bit Depth musn't be reduced below 4.
I personally recommend using 8 because it's Android standard I used 4 in my code to keep the size low.

Size table for 30sec of audio ( uncompressed ):

Sampling rate  | Bit depth | Bit rate | size
| ------------- | ------------- | ------------- | ------------- |
|8,000 | 8 | 64,000 | 234 kb |
|8,000  | 4 | 32,000 | 117 kb |
|11,025 | 8 | 88,200 | 322 kb |
|11,025 | 4 | 44,100 | 161 kb |
|16,000 | 8 | 128,000 | 468 kb |
|16,000 | 4 | 64,000 | 234 kb |

With the code on your repo it would be : 
24,000 * 0.666 * 1 = 16000
And a bit depth of 0.666 which is  not usual ( see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audio_bit_depth ) and results in bad sound quality 

Using my changes it is working on my mobile.

doc.content:
Telegram fails to detect some Emoji copied from other apps
When coping messages from some apps, specially whatsapp and that message has Emoji in it and pasting that message into Telegram some of the Emojis will not be replaced with emoji images and will stay as text. (see picture).
In my phone these are displayed since my font has them while on other phones they will be hidden.
I looked at the ascii of one message i copied from whatsapp and found that it uses the "SB Unicode" to represent the emoji while Telegram only detects "UTF16" encoded ones. (whatsapp can still detect both representations)
(see: http://punchdrunker.github.io/iOSEmoji/table_html/)

Here is a picture of a message I copied from whatsapp adn pasted into Telegram showing the emoji that didn't get replaced:
![telegramemoji](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/432460/2317392/b42ea1fc-a34b-11e3-879d-fe35119a592b.png)

comments.content:
I wrote this code https://github.com/fduraibi/Telegram/commit/3611c037df9fe2298e7effe5037c87a821aa9d8d not super efficient but it is the best that I came up with do and it does the job.

I first created a hashmap wit all emoji mappings from SB_Unicode to UTF16
and whenever the text in the text area changes my function will go through the new changed text and scan for Emoji using the SB_Unicode and change them to UTF16 so Telegram can understand them.

So this is useful now if you are copying something from whatsapp and pasting it into Telegram.

My next update will be to also scan messages received from others to fix the encoding if any (reusing the same function).

doc.content: Unread counter

Enable SQLite secure_delete pragma.
By default, when a row is deleted, its contents are preserved until its space is requested for a new insertion. This makes possible to extract the contents from deleted messages, even the ones encrypted and self-destroyed.

When SQLite has its secure_delete pragma activated and a row is deleted, it overwrites its contents with zeros, making harder to recover the text.

Thanks to Abel Gomez from INCIDE for noticing this (http://atrapadosporlosbits.blogspot.com.es/2014/02/destruccion-de-mensajes-en-telegram.html).

doc.content:
Better detect if no connection is available. Offline mode.
If someone connects only via WiFi (no data plan) and exists the AP coverage area, then while offline opens Telegram, the application appears to be trying to establish a connection.

Other messaging apps, including the now deleted "unofficial Telegram", treated this case properly by detecting there is no connection and then entering an offline mode. Same if connected to a free WiFi network that requires authentication (eg. in an airport).

Apart from aesthetic implications (the circle notification), this may have battery implications (CPU cycles for unnecessary reconnection attempts), but also cause a failure to reconnect once the user actually connects to a new AP.

Not sure how other messaging apps do this, maybe by regularly pinging the servers (see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6493517/android-detect-if-device-has-internet-connection), maybe by using some new Android API method? But note, in the latter case it may indicate there is a connection, not necessarily that the device can reach the Telegram servers.

I just confimed it, there's no need to hide the key.

Because it's [based on the certificate](https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/android/start#get_an_android_certificate_and_the_google_maps_api_key) you use to sign the app, and only you have access to the private key to sign it.

So no, you don't need to hide the Maps API key —just keep your `release.keystore` private.

comments.content: Forgive my previous comment. I see your point now, but this can still be implemented. The API's messages.forwardMessage forwards a message, the message exists only once in the database in order to preserve space, even if it has been forwarded by many users. This is not possible with secret chats because they are encrypted client-side. But here is what can be done: One can create "emulated forwarding", from a user's perspective it's just like normal forwarding. But in the background: The message is downloaded, then re-uploaded as a new message. This will not need the API's forward function because from the API's perspective it is a new message and not a forwarded message. I kindly ask for this issue to be re-opened, in case there's something I missed, I'd love to hear it.

comments.content: This is not, and never will be solvable. Secret chats assume your peer is a trusted friend who also wants to leave no trace of your chats. If you don't trust your friend, the self-destruct mechanism is useless. Telegram has an open client API, people can always save chats which are meant to be destroyed by using alternative clients which don't destroy your messages, or by programming their own client. This even happened with the closed source Snapchat. To sum it up: If your friend is determined on keeping a message designated for deletion, your friend will succeed. Don't send a self-destructing message if you suspect your friend has an interest in keeping it. On a technical side, this is not possible with Android because the Android API Prevents overriding the behavior of some buttons such as the home button.

comments.content:
As you see i went through the translation and added a few comments. I hope some of them are helpful.

Some overall thoughts:
- I personally prefer ellipsis without whitespace (e.g. "schreibt...")
- I dont prefer "Chat" over "Unterhaltung" but there might be some advantages. Chat is shorter (might be good for layout) and its the way whatsapp names it too. Also every german knows the term Chat so it doesnt need to be translated. But again i dont prefer one or the other, just my thoughts.
- I do prefer "Fragen zu Telegram" over "Fragen über Telegram" because it sounds(feels) more natural, more like you would actually speak
- I do prefer "WISCHEN ZUM ABBRECHEN" for the same reason as before

I want to thank the Telegram guys and the translators for their great job. Hopefully some of my suggestions can help. Im also glad to provide further help if needed.

One last not really translation specific detail. There cant be more than 100% security (my heart bleeds when i read this sloppy expression) ;-)

comments.content:
@eppesuig Yes, Transifex is a (great) translation service, and IMHO it is much much much (did I say much) better than working with a repository & pull requests.
Here are some advantages:
- the base translation (English) can be fetched automatically from GitHub (in our case it is [/res/values/strings.xml](https://raw.github.com/DrKLO/Telegram/master/TMessagesProj/src/main/res/values/strings.xml)). So, when the repository is updated, the new strings to be translated appear automatically in Transifex
- it offers a common place to discuss about translations (see for instance https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/telegram/language/it/discussions/)
- there's a simple and yet very powerful translations interface: there's no need to work on text files with some text editor, you can view only untranslated entries, you can add comments and discussions to every string
- it implements a common and clear place where translators are structured in coordinators, reviewers and translators, and having some reference people for translations is great (both for the project maintainer and for other translators)
- the repository on GitHub won't be filled up by thousands of concurrent and overlapping translation-related pull request
- there's a great command-line tool (the so-called *Transifex client*) that allow to fetch the translations from the Transifex server, so this process can be integrated into the build process to have always up-to-date translation files

Best wishes

comments.content:
> the first point only get's an advantage if the translation has allready been moved to Transifex and is completely invalid if not

I don't understand what you mean. What do you mean with "if the translation has allready been moved to Transifex"? Moving to Transifex is very easy, and IMHO it has already been done (see the [Telegram project](https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/telegram/) on Transifex).
What remains is to take out the languages from the GitHub repository (the `strings.xml` files from the `main/res/values-…` folders) and create a build task that fetches them from Transifex, or creating a scheduled task that periodically fetches these translations and updates the repository.
IMHO the second option is better, since we have also a history of changes maintained by commits. 

> IMHO GitHub offers a very comfortable place for discussions too (how do I drop images in Transifex discussions again;-)

I agree with you that GitHub offers a better discussion system: it's really powerful. BTW, I think it's quite a mess to have core-related discussions mixed with language-related discussions. Let's think to the future: if Telegram will get translated in 50 languages (like for instance for [concrete5](https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/concrete5/)), how many translations-related discussions we'll have? In Transifex every translators' group have its own place, and everything is really clean and clear.

> some people like working on text files with some text editor (unlike an overdressed and slow web interface, it is fast and good for overview and keeping things in context)

In Transifex you can always download the text file, translate it offline and upload it. You can do it also via shell scripts (using the Transifex client). So, people that want to work with a comfortable interface can use the Transifex client, and people that prefer text files are free to do it.

> beside it's fine structure. The coordinators, reviewers and translators it feels closed and restricted in a way too

IMHO it's a better approach. Let's do an example: what if someone submit a pull request in GitHub to update a language file? Who decides if that PR is valid and, for instance, does not contain fake translations (buy Viagra or something like this)? Currently, only the repo maintainer can accept/refuse pull requests, but he may not know the specific language (for instance, I really don't understand anything of Chinese texts...).
Under Transifex the translations can be accepted by every translation groups maintainers: the GitHub repo maintainer does not have to do it, and the Transifex maintainers should know what they are doing...

Best regards,
Michele

"Ordinary Messages
Telegram is a cloud-based messenger. In order for you to have access to your messages, photos and videos from all your devices, we store your ordinary chats on our servers. The stored messages are, of course, encrypted."

Show error message when trying to start secret chat with no connection
I was going to show Telegram to a friend, and pressed "start new secret chat". I wasn't online, but thought "what the heck". I was surprised to see the app ignored every single input and displayed the "loading" message until I was once again online.

Telegram is an amazing software, and I want more people using it, so I'd like to suggest the following change: When trying to start a new secret chat, Telegram should check if the phone is connected to the Internet. If it isn't, an error message should be displayed, something along the lines of: "Secret chats can only be set up when you're online". 

If I had the time right now, I'd roll up my sleeves and code it myself, but while that doesn't happen, there is the suggestion for anyone with the time to do it.

Thanks!

"Terminate all other sessions" doesn't terminate Webogram session

- Go to the Android client and click on Settings - Terminate all other sessions

comments.content:
I would like to understand why WhatsApp can achieve a 20 second recorded video transmission within 1 min 12 seconds . Yet it takes telegram 6 minutes 20 seconds. Using the same connection, same phone, same time of day. Well lets look at file sizes sent, we see Whatsapp video size is 4.3MB 352x640 (19 seconds)  , Telegram 23MB 720 x 1280 (19 seconds).  

To match or better WhatsApp the main rival, we need to offer the 'option' to resize the recorded video on top of the option to compress. I would recommend high, medium and low for usability under a guise of 'quality' vs 'bandwidth', perhaps offering  3 customizable settings behind 3 buttons presented as a final stage in the composition of the video. 'Mobile', "Lan" and "Best".  Maybe also provide the option to 'save for this connection type' and not ask again. Later changeable in the application settings of course.  This way, unwitting users get to see this enhanced ability over what WhatsApp provides whilst not risking the chance of getting in the way. At best you exceed in making a smaller or at least comparable file size over WhatsApp, but provide options above and beyond. Adding the option to up the quality level for those on fast connections / not needing to conserve bandwidth on mobile data tariffs.  

Currently the level of compression and no resizing results in a file size that is not best suited to a default setting.  This test was conducted on the Motorola 'Moto G'  (Android 4.4.4) over a WiFi lan connection, connected to the internet via a ~60Mbps ADSL uplink. http://www.speedtest.net/my-result/3895932800

As a side note; the upload to Telegram provided a throughput of 495.832 Kbps, WhatsApp; 489.244 Kbps, so both over a basic internet connection appear to offer the same throughput. So its all down to what you can do in the app.

comments.author: DrKLO

comments.content:
In this instance, this is nothing to do with the GPU or CPU. On Moto G for instance, the actual downsize and compression operation appears to be failing, and a fall back position of sending the native video happens instead, hence a slower upload time coupled with much greater data usage. This has real world cost implications for users! Perhaps offering a fall back position where you revert to using a suitable device codec, because successfully downsizing of videos across a wider range of devices, means people don't get financially stung for exceeding unnecessarily high data usage. Add this to the fact that it will be far faster overall to complete sending of a video of 1 fifth the size, this offsetts any pre processing delays somewhat.

So to confirm, the video being recorded from the message thread in Telegram, via the paperclip, results in a video being taken that does NOT end up downsized and re-compressed. The native video is sent instead. 

I checked this from both within a 'Secret Chat' and a normal message type.
comments.author: Ninja-Duckie

comments.content:
Telegram doesn't wait while video will be compressed, I implemented compressing and sending video in parallel. And yes, it will send uncompressed if something will fail. If you using not stock firmware for your device, this also can be a reason. I know that it doesn't work for some cyanogen Android.

I'm using rendering to surface for MediaCodec which google implemented in Android 4.3 to avoid manual conversion between RGB and YUV, so OpenGL is the onliest option for me. There are 7000 different android devices with different hardware encoders, which requires different YUV formats and paddings between Y and UV planes. This is the reason why video compression doesn't work so good on Android 4.1 and 4.2. I spent about month to deal with this very bad Android API, and of course it steel not good. Maybe Android L will fix something.

comments.content:
Hola Víctor,

En català, les ordres es donen en imperatiu, no en infinitu (els típics cartells de "No fumeu" són un exemple). Així es com també es localitza tot el programari (des d'Android a Windows, passant per les aplicacions web de Google o la gran majoria d'aplicacions que són programari lliure).

De fet, en anglés també s'utilitzen imperatius (Open) i no infinitius ("To Open"). En moltes altres llengües romàniques també s'utilitzen imperatius. No obstant en castellà si que utilitzen infinitius.
comments.author: xavivars

comments.content:
Gràcies per l'explicació Xavi, però crec que l'imperatiu no s'hauria d'utilitzar a tot arreu.

Aqui és correcte ja que dona una ordre a l'usuari:
`<string name="RegisterText">Introduïu el nom i els cognoms</string>`

Però aquí és l'usuari qui vol realitzar una acció, no és imperatiu:
`<string name="CancelRegistration">Cancel·la el registre</string>`
per tant hauria de ser:
`<string name="CancelRegistration">(Jo vull) Cancel·lar el registre</string>`

Jo ho veig així, però podria estar equivocat.
comments.author: vpont

comments.content:
Hola Víctor,

En aquest cas, és l'usuari qui li dóna una ordre a la màquina ("Tu, ordinador, cancel·la el registre") i per això està la diferència: l'ordinador li parla a l'usuari de "vos", en canvi l'usuari a l'ordinador de "tu".

Pots comprovar-ho, per exemple, si estàs identificat al Google i vols sortir; no diu `(Jo vull) Sortir`, sinó `(Tu, ordinador) Surt`

Més informació: http://www.softcatala.org/wiki/Guia_d%27estil/Guia_2010/Tota#Formes_verbals

Add setting to disable automatic "new user" notifications. Also, consider to make it opt-in
When one of my contacts signs up for Telegram, I receive an automatic notification and a new chat is opened.

I'm not sure if this is my Telegram client opening the chats automatically when a new contact is detected, or the remote Telegram clients actively opening chats when they sign in.

This can be an issue with privacy, as not everyone would be happy sending/receiving these notifications, but also an annoyance. For example, if one has contacts in other countries with different time zones, that person could be receiving these notifications during night time.

In any case, it would be good to have an option to disable this feature. And maybe also consider to make it "opt-in", as in, disabled by default.

Cheers

doc.content:
Telegram doesn't receive notifications when phone is locked and main interface was open
Platform:
Android

Case scenario:
Someone is using Telegram, and then locks the screen without closing Telegram first.

Issue:
All subsequent messages won't be notified, because Telegram is the active application, and it will assume the user is watching the screen.

Expected behaviour:
Notifications should go through whenever the phone is locked, even if the app was open when the user locked it.

comments.content:
If user locked his phone Activity onPause() will be called:
https://github.com/DrKLO/Telegram/blob/master/TMessagesProj/src/main/java/org/telegram/ui/ApplicationActivity.java#L330

And if lastPauseTime != 0:
https://github.com/DrKLO/Telegram/blob/master/TMessagesProj/src/main/java/org/telegram/messenger/MessagesController.java#L4484

This code will show notification.

Or I'm wrong, and there is no onPause() by locking the phone?
comments.author: DrKLO

comments.content: Just checked it, onPause() called and notifications on my devices works fine. But there is definitely problems on some devices or android versions, that prevent notifications from work. Can you tell on which device and android version you experiencing this problem?
comments.author: DrKLO

comments.content:
This is how notifications are work in Telegram app:
1) All notifications from our servers go through GCM to your device
2) Application receive this notification and than will connect to Telegram servers to download new messages
3) After downloading all new messages, it will show notificatons(last received message from server)

So there is somewhere problem in first step, so application don't know that it need to download new messages from server and show it. We trying to figure out where this problem, but there is no success yet.

Or if you right and onPause() method can't be called when user lock his phone, it can explain everything.

doc.content:
Possible MITM attack
There is another "tab" for MITM (at least in android client and in the documentation there are no clues of it) :
Even in the corrected version of Diffie-Hellman (with nonce removed) the server can slip customers a number which is zero modulo p as g_a or g_b (since the documentation says about the 2048- bit sequence -- it can be either 0 or p itself). Then both clients will see the same identicon ("visualization key", 'cause it will be a presentation of SHA1 applied to zero).
However, judging by further manipulation with the "shared secret" key (because MTProto doesn't use Diffie-Hellman method of multiplying by g^ab^-1 or any multiplication by the shared key whatsoever) the multiplication by zero will not happen with client messages and they will successfully flow through the "bare" AES ( and therefore users will think that everything is fine and will proceed to transmitting sensitive data in this mode ).

P. S.: even after recent commit function isGoodGaAndGb doesn't check g_a and g_p for zero equality.

http://habrahabr.ru/post/206900/#comment_7128970
https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=6953514

[Bug] Notifications about mentions seems broken
App version: 2.6.1 (479)

When you were `@mentioned` in group, android app uses notification sound from particular group settings instead of private messages one.

What I was tried:

---

#### Case 1 
###### App settings:
- Private messages notifications sound **on**
- Group notifications sound **off**

###### Chat settings: 
**unchanged** after chat creating

###### Result:
Personal message sound: **yes**
Group message sound: **no**
Mention in group sound: **no**  _<-- why?_ :cry: 

---

#### Case 2 
###### App settings:
- Private messages notifications sound **on**
- Group notifications sound **on**

###### Chat settings: 
**unchanged** after chat creating, but **muted**

###### Result:
Personal message sound: **yes**
Group message sound: **no**
Mention in group sound: **yes**

---

#### Case 3 
###### App settings:
- Private messages notifications sound **on**
- Group notifications sound **off**

###### Chat settings: 
Sound: **on**, but **muted**

###### Result:
Personal message sound: **yes**
Group message sound: **no**
Mention in group sound: **yes**

---

I want to be notified (by sound) about private messages and mentions -- somebody waiting for my answer. I want to know about new messages in unmuted groups (status bar), but only when I have some free time to look at the phone (no sound for general messages).

The problems with cases 2 and 3 are: 
1. While chat is muted I have no notifications in the status bar (about general messages in this chat) until I will be mentioned in this muted chat.
2. I have to mute each chat manually - it's inconvenient

Feature Request - improvements on audio messages
1. Make the record button easier for one-handed operation while walking (similar to the space bar?)
2. Show read/unread status for audio messages just like text messages

Feature Request - Present contacts at top level instead of conversations 
Because of the way secret chats work it seems like having multiple conversations with one person is the norm with Telegram for some usage patterns. 

It would be excellent if Telegram treated the "person" I am talking with as the top-level UI element, then allowed me to either:

- drill down and see all my conversations with a person, select one
or
- see my messages to that person in a unified chat like in Hangouts. This would require "hiding" the implementation detail of having a separate secret chat for each of the remote user's devices. My client would have to separately encrypt and copy each secret chat message I send to the remote client's devices, etc.

Feature Request - Allow renaming of chat threads
When I have multiple chats with a single person, it would be nice to be able to rename them to indicate the topic, instead of having to click through them to find out which one I need. 

Hangouts allows this for group threads, but since Telegram secret chats are per-device I have a number of open conversations with the same person.

No, it does not. The Emoji sets differ a lot between devices / manufacturers. Therefore they can lead to confusion and can be lost in translation. It's all explained over there:

> @GermainZ wrote:
> 
> The Telegram Android app creates an uneven experience for the user.

Wrong. It's actually doing the exact opposite.

My experience is much more even when I (and my chat partners) have the same Emojis in Telegram across all platforms.

By the way:

From a technical point, I would agree that using native Emojis (i.e. using a font) would be better than using images.

But I am only saying this because the Emojis in Telegram for Android currently suffer from image compression, as mentioned in:

https://github.com/DrKLO/Telegram/issues/914

And using native Emojis (i.e. relying on an actual font instead of images) would result in higher quality Emojis.

But then again this could be adressed by using PNG instead of JPEG.

As long as most devices have different Emojis (Samsung has it's own, LG has it's own, HTC has it's own, Google has it's own, Apple has it's own, Microsoft has it's own and so on...), I think the way it's done in Telegram for Android is the best.

Because it ensures that everyone sees the same Emojis and they can not be lost in translation as described in the following article:

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/27/emoji-meaning_n_5530638.html

If one Emoji font would be made a standard and everyone would use this standard, so that every device would have the same Emoji font, then I would agree that native Emojis should be used.

But since that unfortunately hasn't happened yet, I think Telegram for Android should go on with keeping it's specific set and specific Emoji drawer to make Emojis consistent for Telegram across all platforms.

But it still would be nice if @DrKLO would switch to PNG to make the Emojis have a higher image quality as mentioned in https://github.com/DrKLO/Telegram/issues/914.

Then the image quality would no longer lack behind native Emojis and everything would be fine.

Regards

comments.content:
> @Multimoon wrote:
> 
> When you tap a emoji on your keyboard, you should
> expect to see the same emoji entered in on the text field.

If you would use the Emoji drawer that is built into Telegram for Android, instead of using the system's keyboard, you wouldn't have this problem (at least as long as you do not enter more than 50 Emojis at once).

And actually I personally think the Emoji drawer that is built into Telegram for Android is better for Emojis than most other Emoji keyboards which are built into system keyboards.

That's because:

* The Telegram for Android Emoji drawer button next to the message input box allows me to instantly switch between the Emoj drawer and the keyboard with just a press of one button. On keyboards like the one that ships with my device or the Google keyboard or SwiftKey for example, I have to press several buttons and/or have to press and hold buttons to reach the Emoji keyboard, which gets annoying very quickly. If you have a workaround for this, feel free to explain.
* On the Telegram for Android Emoji drawer scrolling through an Emoji section works vertically (swiping from top to bottom), which is quite intuitive and makes for a good feeling IMHO. On other keyboards like the one that ships with my device or the Google keyboard for example, scrolling through an Emoji section works horizontally (swiping from left to right), which I personally do not like at all. I really hate that.
* On the Telegram for Android Emoji drawer, I can see eight Emojis in one row and more than four rows of Emojis at once. On other keyboards like the one that ships with my device or the Google keyboard or SwiftKey for example, I can only see seven Emojis in one row and mostly only three rows of Emojs at once. So the Emoji drawer in Telegram for Android shows singnificantly more Emojis at once, which makes choosing and selecting among hundreds of Emojis easier.


So I actually do not want to use the Emoji keyboard from a system keyboard (because of the reasons mentioned above) and prefer the one that is built into Telegram for Android. And if it's background would be a bit brighter (https://github.com/DrKLO/Telegram/issues/843), it would be even better.

doc.content:
Better feedback for shared messages, and ability to edit them.
When sharing something to Telegram (tapping the "share" button in another app, eg. YouTube, Twitter), there is a number of problems:

* There is nearly no indication that you're currently sharing something. At the top, "Select Chat" is displayed - **replacing this** with "Share with..." would make things a lot more apparent.
* A default Android yes / no box appears when tapping a chat to share in containing "Send messages to [user]?". Not only is this incredibly unclear, but also cumbersome and irritating. Simply removing this would be an improvement.
* **There is no way to edit a shared message before sending it.** This is by far the most important one. Twitter, for example, adds a weird little blurb ("Check out @obskyr's tweet!") in addition to the link you want to share - being able to edit this before sending would be really nice, and replace the "are you sure?" textbox.

For an example of the last one, check how Hangouts does it. Hangouts does do the "choose chat" step a bit differently (which doesn't matter in this case), but it lets you edit afterward.

Feature request: quote message
My friends and I often use the Forward function to repeat an old message back to the same group, in order to then reply to it. This requires selecting the message, tapping the forward button, and selecting the same group again. But there's no easy way to see which group it was coming from and we often hit the wrong group.

A very simple enhancement would be a "quote" button next to the forward button in the action bar. It would simply forward the message to the current group.

Feature request - "Smart notifications" for group chats
So, chats with more than 5 people are sometimes mighty annoying when they start beeping with a message every 10 seconds. And yes, I know there is of course a "mute" button, as I believe it was previously discussed, however, Viber messenger had an absolutely genius approach here that would be, I hope, very easy to implement:

They had "Smart Notifications" as an option for each individual group chat. If a group chat was set to "Smart notifications", the phone would beep for the first and second message, and then it would simply go quiet *for that particular chat* and not beep any more at all until that chat is open and read.

The benefit of this would be that, unlike in muted group chats, you would at least have the first 1 or 2 sounds so that you would know that the chat is active and that you need to look at it later. I am not a big fan at all for fully muting conversations, and I think this idea worked brilliantly in Viber. But Viber is rubbish, while Telegram is so much better and I would love to have this option there.


Thanks for all the great work!

comments.content:
The progress is somewhat complicated at the moment, you can translate using Transifex (Make sure you select the Android, official project):
https://www.transifex.com/projects/p/telegram/

Click the desired language and join the team if you aren't already in.
After joining you'll be able to translate.
After translating just download the file from the same dialog that appears when you click the language name from the language selection screen.
Save that file and change its name to `strings.xml` and then send it to yourself via Telegram.
ATTENTION: the file name must be exactly `strings.xml` otherwise it won't work!!

A file download request will appear for your Telegram on Android, click the down arrow to download it and then click the 3 dots on the top right corner and select "Apply localization file".

The internal language selection screen will appear, select your language and you'll be able to use it from now on.

Kind regards,
Yaron Shahrabani.

How do you bypass disabled screenshots without taking an actual picture of the phone? Maybe only on a rooted device. I have not tried, but it might work. I may be wrong, so please correct me if so.

I am also not aware of devices that do not support this feature. Older Android versions do not support screenshots at all (except rooted ones) and the newer ones that I have tested do support it. It is an Android built-in feature and only if a vendor removes it, it will not work.

I think that it is an important feature in many scenarios. For example, when on a private chat with the self-destruct option enabled, one party can take screenshots of the conversation and reveal them to the public. Or in the case when someone has physical access to a device, might want to take a screenshot of some private conversation and forward it to himself.

In the beginning my goal was to have an option to disable screenshots at conversation level, so that it is guaranteed that both parties cannot take screenshots, but because Telegram does not handle conversations as activities, it is impossible without a restart. An indicator on private chats could notify whether the other party can take screenshots or not.

Obviously this feature does not aim to substitute the already existing security, but it can give it a boost.

Quesiton: Are secret chats secure assuming MTProto isn't?
Many websites are criticizing MTProto for being a bleeding-edge, untested crypto. This may or may not be correct, this is irrelevant to my question. Let us assume the worst case scenario: MTProto is fully broken. Secret chats use Diffie-Hellman key exchange, which is known to be secure. Which leads to my quesiton:

Are DH and MTproto bundled tightly in such a  way that a weakness in MTProto breaks Diffie-Hellman? or is it safe to assume that Diffie-Hellman is loosely coupled in such a way that it will remain secure even in case MTProto turns out to be weak?

comments.content:
Diffie-Hellman as a protocol is secure, however, if it was implemented in an incorrect way then it won't be secure anymore. Similarly the badly broken wireless encryption WEP is based on RC4 which is generally secure but it the implementation has problems that led to it being weak. It got replaced first by WPA-TKIP which also uses RC4 but with a good implementation.

Also since the key exchange still passes through the Telegram servers then there is nothing that stop them from intercepting the key-exchange and becoming the middle man. the only way to have a really secure connection is to make a direct connection between the two parties and not through a third entity. Even better, if the keys were exchanged using a different channel from the one used for the communication, like to meet the person physically and exchange keys (most secure way) or to use SMS or anything that is not using the internet.

comments.content:
I am sorry, but your comment is wrong. Please allow me to explain.

In general:
Talking securely over an untrusted channel has been invented decades ago. Please look up "RSA", "Diffie Hellman Key Exchange". Even if you rely on an evil server to facilitate your connection, a secure channel can be established. The only problem: You must first meet with the other party and exchange a so called "key" securely. Once the key is securely exchanged between Bob and Alice (e.g. they meet in a bar and exchange usb sticks) the two people can talk securely forever even if the facilitating server is not secure. This is how PGP, Telegram, and other systems work. At the core lies either Diffie Hellman or RSA.

Telegram-specific:
Telegram uses Diffie Hellman. But instead of meeting in a bar and exchanging USB sticks, you just meet up with your friend and compare these:
![key_image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5030488/3474839/23252750-02e9-11e4-888c-32b7bd377761.jpg)

If the keys look the same on the two phones, then the keys have been exchanged without tampering, and the two people can talk securely, forever.

Note that this would fail if other portions of the protocol are not secure, and this is why I opened this question in the first place ;) . To ask whether other aspects of Telegram are not secure.

If you want to dive into the world of "end to end encryption", I suggest you start with PGP. It works on top of Email, and even though the Evil Email Servers facilitate communication, no one can decrypt it. Unlike Telegram, PGP has proven security. Whether or not Telegram is secure is the topic of this issue.

**Message**

     {
        "type": "text",
        "from": "+447123456789",
        "to": "+4472345678912",

**Image**

Contact-Images
Current behaviour:
Every user can set his own contact image. if the user has no image, there is displayed a default image.

My suggestion:
As above every user can set his own contact image - this image has priority, if there is one, always use this.
if there is *no* contact image set by user, search in the phone contacts, if there is an image: use this.
if there is *no* contact image set by user and there is *no* contact image in the phone contacts: take the first letter of the name combined with a random color. This behaviour is a well-known pattern (google mail, atlassian jira, ...) and helps to identify better than now.

comments.content:
Ok it seems that I did it :D you need to:
1. create a new folder inside org.telegram called "whateveryouwant" (I will now use Telepatch 'cause it's my case, but you can use everything) and place everything that was in org.telegram inside it
2. do replace in path (right click on a folder) on config and on src and replace every org.telegram with org.telegram.telepatch (I suggest ALWAYS using preserve case, just in case!)
2-bis. If you messed up, or just to be sure, do another replace in path on config folder and replace every org.telegram.telepatch.telepatch with org.telegram.telepatch --> that happens. Frequently. Do it also in org.telegram.telepatch folder.
2-again. open androidmanifest inside src/main and do replace all org.telegram to org.telegram.telepatch 
(if not done already)
3. another replace in path like that one, but this time replace in jni folder org/telegram/ with org/telegram/telepatch/
4. last replace in path in jni, replace Java_org_telegram with Java_org_telegram_telepatch
5. rebuild ndk libs from command line (<ndk-path>/ndk-build <your-jni-folder-path>)
6. If it goes in error, you screwed up, do other edit to match the pattern "org.telegram.telepatch"
6-bis. If Android Studio drives nuts, restart it. It helps.
7.try install it. It should work (tested with source of 1.5 stable)

if it goes again in "native method not found", just rebuild the ndk source.

In the end you will have your fork up and working and you can publish it on Google Play Store.

Fix issue #127
Fix issue #127

Resume:

* Make the "CACHE_TAG" string on strings.xml not translatable, see https://github.com/luzfcb/Telegram/commit/96377b23bc6896750905623bbdee5259a7a80ec5
* Create transifex configuration ( .tx/config ) to easy pull and push translations using Transifex client. Please see: 
http://support.transifex.com/customer/portal/articles/995605-installation 
http://support.transifex.com/customer/portal/articles/1000855-configuring-the-client - only ".transifexrc" section
http://support.transifex.com/customer/portal/articles/960804-overview#user-client-08-type
http://support.transifex.com/customer/portal/articles/996157-getting-translations
http://support.transifex.com/customer/portal/articles/996211-pushing-new-translations

* Update Readme to informing that all efforts for translation were moved to Transifex


After pulling translations using a Transifex client, for each translation, Transifex client automatically creates a folder containing the translation

The folder name will be defined according to the following syntax: 

```
TMessagesProj/src/main/res/values-<lang-code>/string.xml
```
