Again, I don't want all chats to be "secret", I just want them to use end-to-end encryption.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but i think this could work:
* Alice and Bob both generate a private and public key for all their devices (say, Phone and Desktop). When Alice sends a message to Bob, the message will be encrypted using Bob's two keys. Now Bob can read the message on his phone and his Desktop.

_or_
* Alice and Bob both generate a keypair that will then be exchanged between their devices. Now Alice can send a message to Bob using his public key and - since he has the private key on all his devices - he can read it anywhere.

I'd rather use the first example though.
This works for ssh, too: I give the server multiple keys for multiple devices and can still access it from anywhere.

3) Choose your telegram contact and "ok"

comments.content:
This feature should receive more attention. Most other chat services will show a thumbnail when someone sends you an image URL, so Telegram should too. If the receiver has limited data, they will have disabled auto-downloading of images, and the same option can apply to this.

The other objections I've seen here are worthy considerations but in no way should they stop us from introducing this feature.
@fduraibi: 

>1- Someone can craft an image/link/file... etc that might misbehave when opened by Telegram

If that happens then we fix Telegram, just like we fix any other bug.

>2- Every receiver of that link will have to download that image at full size (what if i forwarded a link of a 50MB image?)

That's easy to fix by implementing a size limit of, say, 1mb. If the received image is larger than that then it cancels the download and just displays the URL.

@func0der:

>Since this app should bring security, something like this could be used to hijack Telegram and/or complete Android.

Again, if an image file can hijack Telegram and/or Android then this is an issue that should be brought to the forefront and dealt with. I think it's *highly* unlikely though.

>You are right about the link not being touched. No user input should be changed by any means.

What we're proposing is that the URL is sent, received and displayed as usual, and optionally a thumbnail is loaded and displayed above the URL. Nothing is changed, just additional information is provided. The same should be done for Youtube links, and the same thing should be (and is being) done in the other Telegram clients like Webogram. Those sorts of user-facing features are important to ensure Telegram is as good, or better, than other modern IM systems.

Contacts without country code do not sync, not even after adding the country code
When a contact (C0) without country code sends me a message, Telegram asks me to create a new contact (C1), which I do not want. When I then prepend the country code to the contact's phone number in Android 4.4, Telegram still wants me to create a new contact (C1) for that number, even after rebooting the phone. Further investigation shows that a newly created contact (C1) lists the phone number plus country code without any spaces. Adjusting the original contact (C0), such that it does not contain any spaces either, does not fix the issue.

One suggestion to fix some related issues would be to automatically assume the users country code for any contact that is stored without country code. Also, it might be wise to give the user the option to resync his contacts, just like in Whatsapp. I didn't look at the code yet, so I don't know how often synching is actually triggered.

Here is a summery of the cases regarding Telegram notifications: (hope it helps)
1- Using Github source: You have to get your own GCM Keys and API IDs ...etc from Google and Telegram API page for notifications to work.
2- If using a custom ROM (like cyanogen) without installing Google Play (by installing official apk directly) it won't also work, since notifications uses Google Play Services. Install Gapps, and you might also need to log in with a gmail account.
3- If installing from f-droid, it won't work, since they "I believe" removed the dependency of Google Play Services.
4- If installing from Google Play and you don't get notifications then try this solution (i tried it on 3 different phones and it worked) Go to "Settings" and go all the way down and click on "Log Out" (that should cause the app to unregistere its GCM Key, then just to be safe also uninstall the app and install it again. Now when you start the app it will recreate a new GCM Key. (DrKLO told me about  this issue where in some cases an app might have more than one GCM keys that misses things up or something like that)

comments.content:
@DrKLO I see that it is copied, and the code is correct. The problem is that there are other tasks which are running elsewhere in the app and are preventing this code from executing. Since Froyo the task execution is done serially, so if you have other long running tasks performed on devices with SDK >= 11 , your new task will not run, even though the code is correct. At least for me, when I compiled the latest version from GitHub and ran with a debugger on an HTC ONE X device with api 17, I could see that the the code requested the task to execute, but it never did because other tasks were running. Also, the push notifications did not work. When I did the change I described it was indeed called and the push notifications started to work. 
I think it is worth to add this change because the way the code is written now, it is sensitive to other things that happen in the app and if there is a task that was started before it and for some reason doesn't complete on some devices or for some users then this task will not run as well and the essential feature of push notifications will not work.

##### Here is a list of thing that I believe need to be fixed/implemented so people will accept Telegram as a replacement for other messaging apps like Whatsapp, Line, Chaton...etc:

doc.content:
Plug-ins support
Usually people like to have certain features in an app that not everyone wants or agree to and that ends up causing the creation of many forked apps (specially with open source apps). However, if the app support plugins, then developers can right small features as plugins and users will choose what they want to install.

I don't know how such thing can to be implemented but there is few things that need to be in mind while doing it:
1- Security: we don't want bad people making plugins that will cause harmful things, so there need to be guidelines on what do plugins have access to, creating a trusted plugins repository,  warning the user when installing untrusted/unsigned plugins ...etc

2- Version control: maybe app should be aware of what parts of it a plug in is using so in case that part of the app got updated that plugin will get disabled until it is updated accordingly. The app should reject the installation of old plugins that are not compatible anymore.

3- keep them open source: since telegram is GPL does the plugins need to be GPL as well?. Having them open source means they can be reviewed for security reasons also when a plugin is abandoned by its developer some one else can continue the work.

I know this is such a big request at this time, but I thought it would be good to keep it in mind and prepare the future updates to be ready for such feature.

comments.content:
@DrKLO I can't stress to you how important it is for you to improve your git workflow.  For your own benefit, for the project's benefit, and for everyone else's.

Here are the important points:

- Commit as frequently as you like (but clean up for public consumption)
  - Committing often during development is useful, and makes it easy to backtrack
  - Before you push to a public repository, you may use `git rebase` to squash commits down into logical units of work
  - This also transforms the merging of patches from being all-but-impossible to very-manageable
- Use descriptive commit messages
  - Doing so allows everyone (including you) to review changes (and determine what you were doing when you broke something)
  - If you rebase before pushing, you can clean up your commit messages during the rebase
- Use branches
  - Ideally, you should develop features in topic branches
  - If the above seems like too much effort, a simple segregation is to create a `develop` branch that can contain dirty/broken code, that once working can be merged into `master`
- Tag releases
  - Not doing this is just silly, and your excuse that it takes too much time is absolutely ridiculous.
  - It literally takes one second to create a tag
  - Doing so allows tracking of exactly what changed between versions, so that you can tell which versions are affected by a bug, for example

It will be absolutely impossible to maintain this as an open source project until you start using source control responsibly.  You're obviously new to software development, so all this may seem a little overwhelming, but if you think that source control is a waste of time, this project may as well already be dead, or closed source.

Either this project is open source, or it's not.  Having binaries shipped on source that's not even available means this is _not_ open source.
